block.para: Let's analyze what the properties of the orthogonal complement operation mean.
The property ‘If S\subseteq T\subseteq W, then T^{\bot}\subseteq S^{\bot}’. We read this as:

If S is a subset of T or equal to T, and T is a subset of W or equal to W, then the orthogonal complement of T is a subset of the orthogonal complement of S or is equal to the orthogonal complement of S.

li.para: T^{\bot} consists of all those vectors of W which are orthogonal to every vector in T
If every vector in S is also in T, this means that a vector in the orthogonal complement of T is also in the orthogonal complement of S.

block.para: The property S^{\bot} = \span(S)^{\bot}. We read this as:
The orthogonal complement of S is equal to the orthogonal complement of the span of S.

We know that S is contained in \span(S). So we see that \span(S)^{\bot} is contained in S^{\bot} from the previous property. That S^{\bot} is also contained in \span(S)^{\bot} requires proof by computation.
